faculty: Faculty of Mathematics and Materials Science
specialty: Applied Mathematics for Artificial Intelligence and Data Science

program_overview.description: A three-year undergraduate program that integrates fundamental mathematics, applied mathematics, computer science, and data science with strong emphasis on AI applications.
program_overview.structure: Organized into 6 semesters with 30 credits each, comprising Fundamental, Methodological, Discovery, and Transversal teaching units.

objectives: Provide a solid foundation in pure and applied mathematics (analysis, algebra, probability, differential equations)
Develop expertise in artificial intelligence and data science (machine learning, deep learning, NLP, computer vision)
Equip students with computational skills in Python for implementing mathematical models and AI algorithms
Foster interdisciplinary competencies including scientific communication and ethical considerations in AI
Prepare graduates for professional roles in data science, AI, or further academic studies
targeted_profiles: Data analysts, machine learning engineers, or AI specialists in industry sectors like energy, technology, and finance
Researchers with strong mathematical foundation for master's or doctoral studies
Professionals with interdisciplinary skills bridging mathematics, computer science, and AI applications

mathematical_skills: Advanced mathematical concepts (functional analysis, stochastic processes, optimization)
computational_skills: Using AI libraries (TensorFlow, PyTorch, scikit-learn, NLTK)
Implementing AI and data science applications

regional.energy_sector: Ouargla is a hub for Algeria's oil/gas industry. Opportunities with Sonatrach for operational optimization, predictive maintenance, resource exploration analytics
regional.technology_initiatives: Tech startups in agriculture, logistics, urban planning seeking data analysts and AI specialists
regional.education_research: Local universities and research centers for academic projects in applied mathematics and AI

national.technology_it: Growing demand in Algiers, Oran (fintech, e-commerce, telecommunications)
national.public_sector: Government agencies for data-driven policy analysis, digital transformation
national.finance_banking: Risk modeling, fraud detection, algorithmic trading
national.international_companies: Multinational firms in Algeria recruiting for data analytics and AI roles

masters_programs: Applied Mathematics (numerical analysis, optimization, stochastic processes)
Computer Science (machine learning, data science, AI)
Data Science and AI (deep learning, NLP, computer vision)
further_study_pathways.research_academia: Doctoral studies in mathematics, AI, or interdisciplinary fields

courses.name: Analysis I
courses.objectives: Familiarize students with set theory vocabulary, study convergence methods for real sequences, and explore various aspects of the analysis of functions of one real variable.
courses.prerequisites: Mathematics at the level of 3rd-year secondary scientific and technical education.
content: Chapter I: The Field of Real Numbers - ℝ as a commutative and totally ordered field, mathematical induction, intervals, supremum and infimum
Chapter II: The Field of Complex Numbers - Algebraic operations, modulus, trigonometric and exponential forms, Euler's formulas, nth roots
Chapter III: Sequences of Real Numbers - Bounded and convergent sequences, arithmetic operations, infinite limits, Cauchy sequences
Chapter IV: Real Functions of One Real Variable - Function graphs, limits, continuity, uniform continuity, theorems for continuous functions
Chapter V: Differentiable Functions - Derivatives, geometric interpretation, Taylor's formula, local extrema, convexity
Chapter VI: Elementary Functions - Natural logarithm, exponential, hyperbolic functions and their inverses
references: J.-M. Monier, Analyse PCSI-PTSI, Dunod, 2003
Y. Bougrov & S. Nikolski, Cours de Mathématiques Supérieures, Mir, 1983
N. Piskounov, Calcul différentiel et intégral, Tome 1, Mir, 1980
K. Allab, Eléments d'Analyse, OPU, 1984

courses.name: Algebra I
courses.objectives: Introduce fundamental concepts of algebra and set theory.
content: Chapter 1: Logic - Truth tables, quantifiers, types of reasoning
Chapter 2: Sets and Functions - Definitions, injective, surjective, bijective functions, direct and inverse images
Chapter 3: Binary Relations - Reflexive, symmetric, antisymmetric, transitive relations, equivalence relations
Chapter 4: Algebraic Structures - Groups, subgroups, homomorphisms, rings, fields
Chapter 5: Polynomial Rings - Polynomial arithmetic, divisibility, Euclidean division, irreducible factorization
references: M. Mignotte & J. Nervi, Algebre: licences sciences 1ère année, Ellipses, 2004
J. Franchini & J. C. Jacques, Algebre: cours, exercices corrigés, Ellipses, 1996
C. Degrave & D. Degrave, Algebre 1ère année, Bréal, 2003

courses.name: Algorithms and Data Structures I
courses.objectives: Introduce concepts of algorithms and data structures.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction - Brief history of computer science, introduction to algorithmics
Chapter 2: Simple Sequential Algorithms - Algorithm components, variables, data types, basic operations
Chapter 3: Conditional Structures - Simple and compound conditional structures, multiple choice structures
Chapter 4: Loops - While, repeat, for loops, nested loops
Chapter 5: Subprograms - Functions and procedures, local and global variables, recursion
Chapter 6: Arrays and Strings - Array types, multidimensional arrays, string manipulation
references: Algorithms Notions de base, 2013
Algorithmique - 3ème édition, Dunod, 2010
R. Malgouyres et al., Initiation à l'algorithmique et à la programmation en C, Dunod, 2011

courses.name: Discrete Mathematics
courses.objectives: Provide students with foundational concepts in discrete mathematics, essential for computer science and applied mathematics, including logic, set theory, combinatorics, and graph theory basics.
content: Chapter 1: Propositional Logic - Propositions, logical connectives, truth tables, tautologies
Chapter 2: Predicate Logic - Predicates, quantifiers, nested quantifiers, logical inferences
Chapter 3: Set Theory - Sets, subsets, power sets, set operations, Venn diagrams
Chapter 4: Functions and Relations - Injective, surjective, bijective functions, equivalence relations
Chapter 5: Combinatorics - Counting principles, permutations, combinations, binomial theorem
Chapter 6: Introduction to Graph Theory - Graphs, vertices, edges, paths, cycles, trees
references: K. H. Rosen, Discrete Mathematics and Its Applications, McGraw-Hill, 2018
R. P. Grimaldi, Discrete and Combinatorial Mathematics, Pearson, 2004
N. L. Biggs, Discrete Mathematics, Oxford University Press, 2002
courses.note: Practical work includes problem-solving sessions and basic programming exercises

courses.name: Free Software
courses.objectives: Familiarize students with computer tools and the Internet, focusing on open-source software.
content: Chapter 1: Information Technologies - Hardware, software, applications, communication spaces
Chapter 2: Open-Source Tools - History, advantages, licenses, development environments, office suites
references: Microsoft Office 2016, Eni, 2016
Word et Excel 2016 pour les nuls, 2016
M. Gris, Initiation à Internet, Eni, 2009

courses.name: Introduction to Data Visualization
courses.objectives: Introduce students to the principles of data visualization, focusing on creating effective visual representations of data using open-source tools, with applications in mathematics and data science.
courses.prerequisites: Basic computer literacy and introductory mathematics.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction to Data Visualization - Importance of visualization, types of data, principles of effective visualization
Chapter 2: Data Visualization Tools - Overview of open-source tools (Matplotlib, Seaborn, Plotly), visualization in Python
Chapter 3: Basic Visualization Techniques - Plot types: bar charts, line plots, scatter plots, histograms
Chapter 4: Visualizing Mathematical Data - Plotting functions and mathematical relationships, visualizing statistical data
Chapter 5: Best Practices and Design Principles - Avoiding common pitfalls, accessibility and clarity in visualizations
references: E. Tufte, The Visual Display of Quantitative Information, Graphics Press, 2001
C. Ware, Information Visualization: Perception for Design, Morgan Kaufmann, 2020
J. VanderPlas, Python Data Science Handbook, O'Reilly, 2016
courses.note: Tutorials focus on hands-on exercises using Python libraries like Matplotlib

courses.name: Academic English for AI and Data Science
courses.objectives: Familiarize students with academic and technical English in mathematics and computer science, improving reading, writing, listening, and speaking skills.
content: Reading Comprehension and Technical Vocabulary - Analyzing scientific texts, learning technical vocabulary
Writing Skills - Writing sentences/paragraphs on mathematical concepts, emails, technical summaries
Listening Comprehension and Pronunciation - Analyzing scientific videos/lectures, recognizing technical terms
Speaking Skills and Communication - Simple presentations, role-playing, discussions
references: R. Murphy, English Grammar in Use, Cambridge, 2004
M. McCarthy & F. O'Dell, English Vocabulary in Use, Cambridge, 1994
L. Rozakis, English Grammar for the Utterly Confused, McGraw-Hill, 2003
courses.teaching_methodology: Interactive approach with authentic documents, practical exercises, quizzes, assignments, presentations

courses.name: Analysis II
courses.objectives: Deepen knowledge of differential and integral calculus of functions of one real variable, and introduce numerical sequences and series.
content: Chapter I: Numerical Sequences and Series - Geometric series, harmonic series, comparison tests, power series
Chapter II: Integrals - Riemann integral, properties, fundamental theorem of calculus, integration techniques
Chapter III: Differential Equations - First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients
Chapter IV: Functions of Several Variables - Limits, continuity, partial derivatives, gradient, extrema
references: J.-M. Monier, Analyse PCSI-PTSI, Dunod, 2003
N. Piskounov, Calcul différentiel et intégral, Tome 1, Mir, 1980
K. Allab, Eléments d'Analyse, OPU, 1984

courses.name: Algebra II
courses.objectives: Deepen knowledge of linear algebra, focusing on vector spaces, matrices, and linear transformations.
content: Chapter I: Vector Spaces - Definition, subspaces, linear independence, basis, dimension
Chapter II: Matrices - Matrix operations, determinants, inverse matrices, rank
Chapter III: Linear Transformations - Definitions, kernel, image, eigenvalues, eigenvectors
Chapter IV: Applications - Solving linear systems, geometric transformations
references: M. Mignotte & J. Nervi, Algebre: licences sciences 1ère année, Ellipses, 2004
J. Franchini & J. C. Jacques, Algebre: cours, exercices corrigés, Ellipses, 1996
S. Balac & F. Sturm, Algebre et analyse, PPUR, 2003

courses.name: Algorithms and Data Structures 2
courses.objectives: Build on Algorithms and Data Structures 1 to introduce advanced algorithmic concepts and data structures, with practical implementation in C.
courses.prerequisites: Algorithms and Data Structures I or equivalent.
content: Chapter 1: Advanced Algorithms - Algorithm analysis, time and space complexity, Big-O notation
Chapter 2: Sorting Algorithms - Bubble sort, insertion sort, selection sort, quick sort, merge sort
Chapter 3: Data Structures - Linked lists, stacks and queues, binary trees, traversals
Chapter 4: Recursion - Recursive algorithms, divide-and-conquer, examples
Chapter 5: Practical Implementation - Coding sorting algorithms and data structures in C
references: Algorithmique - 3ème édition, Dunod, 2010
R. Malgouyres et al., Initiation à l'algorithmique et à la programmation en C, Dunod, 2011
T. H. Cormen et al., Introduction to Algorithms, MIT Press, 2009

courses.name: Probability and Descriptive Statistics
courses.objectives: Introduce fundamental concepts of probability and descriptive statistics, with an emphasis on Bayesian methods.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction to Probability - Sample spaces, events, probability axioms, conditional probability, Bayes' theorem
Chapter 2: Random Variables - Discrete and continuous random variables, probability distributions
Chapter 3: Descriptive Statistics - Measures of central tendency, measures of dispersion, data visualization
Chapter 4: Bayesian Statistics - Bayesian inference, prior and posterior distributions, Bayes' theorem applications
references: J. E. Freund, Mathematical Statistics with Applications, Pearson, 2014
D. C. Montgomery & G. C. Runger, Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers, Wiley, 2014
J. O. Berger, Statistical Decision Theory and Bayesian Analysis, Springer, 1985
courses.note: Practical work includes statistical computations and visualizations

courses.name: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
courses.objectives: Provide an overview of artificial intelligence concepts, including machine learning basics, with practical applications relevant to applied mathematics.
courses.prerequisites: Basic programming, Algorithms and Data Structures I.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction to AI - History and definitions of AI, applications in mathematics and data science
Chapter 2: Machine Learning Basics - Supervised vs. unsupervised learning, linear regression, classification
Chapter 3: Data Preprocessing - Data cleaning, normalization, feature selection and engineering
Chapter 4: Simple AI Models - Decision trees, k-nearest neighbors, introduction to neural networks
Chapter 5: Practical Implementation - Implementing basic AI algorithms in Python
references: S. J. Russell & P. Norvig, Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach, Pearson, 2020
A. Géron, Hands-On Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn, Keras, and TensorFlow, O'Reilly, 2019
T. M. Mitchell, Machine Learning, McGraw-Hill, 1997
courses.note: Practical work (TP) in Python, using libraries like scikit-learn

courses.name: Mathematical Physics Equations
courses.objectives: Introduce mathematical methods for solving fundamental equations in physics, focusing on their applications in modeling physical phenomena.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction to Physical Modeling - Role of mathematics in physics, types of physical equations
Chapter 2: Ordinary Differential Equations in Physics - Harmonic oscillator, damped systems, applications in mechanics
Chapter 3: Partial Differential Equations - Wave equation, heat equation, boundary and initial conditions
Chapter 4: Numerical Methods - Finite difference methods for PDEs, basic simulations
references: G. B. Arfken & H. J. Weber, Mathematical Methods for Physicists, Academic Press, 2012
M. L. Boas, Mathematical Methods in the Physical Sciences, Wiley, 2005
J. R. Taylor, Classical Mechanics, University Science Books, 2005
courses.note: Practical work includes numerical simulations using Python

courses.name: Fundamentals of Programming and Scientific Computing with Python
courses.objectives: Teach foundational programming skills in Python and their application to scientific computing in mathematics and data science.
courses.prerequisites: Basic computer literacy, Algorithms and Data Structures I.
content: Chapter 1: Python Basics - Variables, data types, control structures, functions, modules
Chapter 2: Scientific Computing Libraries - NumPy (arrays, linear algebra), SciPy (numerical methods), Matplotlib (plotting)
Chapter 3: Numerical Methods - Solving linear systems, root finding, numerical integration
Chapter 4: Applications - Simulating mathematical models, data analysis and visualization
references: J. VanderPlas, Python Data Science Handbook, O'Reilly, 2016
A. B. Downey, Think Python, O'Reilly, 2015
H. P. Langtangen, A Primer on Scientific Programming with Python, Springer, 2016
courses.note: Practical work focuses on implementing numerical algorithms in Python

courses.name: Analysis III
courses.objectives: Study advanced topics in analysis, including functions of several variables, multiple integrals, and differential equations.
content: Chapter 1: Functions of Several Variables - Limits, continuity, partial derivatives, gradient, directional derivatives, chain rule, Taylor's theorem
Chapter 2: Optimization - Extrema of functions, Hessian matrix, Lagrange multipliers, constrained optimization
Chapter 3: Multiple Integrals - Double and triple integrals, change of variables, polar, cylindrical, spherical coordinates, applications in physics and geometry
Chapter 4: Differential Equations - Systems of linear differential equations, existence and uniqueness theorems, series solutions, special functions
references: J. E. Marsden & A. J. Tromba, Vector Calculus, W. H. Freeman, 2012
N. Piskounov, Calcul différentiel et integral, Tome 2, Mir, 1980
J. Stewart, Calculus: Early Transcendentals, Cengage Learning, 2015

courses.name: Algebra III
courses.objectives: Deepen knowledge of linear algebra, focusing on advanced topics in vector spaces, linear transformations, and applications.
content: Chapter 1: Advanced Vector Spaces - Review of vector spaces, bases, dimension, dual spaces, quotient spaces, linear forms and applications
Chapter 2: Linear Transformations - Eigenvalues, eigenvectors, eigenspaces, diagonalization, Jordan canonical form, spectral theorem for symmetric matrices
Chapter 3: Inner Product Spaces - Inner products, norms, orthogonality, orthogonal and orthonormal bases, Gram-Schmidt process
Chapter 4: Applications - Quadratic forms and their applications, singular value decomposition (introduction), applications in geometry and data science
references: M. Mignotte & J. Nervi, Algebre: licences sciences 1ère année, Ellipses, 2004
S. Lang, Linear Algebra, Springer, 2004
G. Strang, Introduction to Linear Algebra, Wellesley-Cambridge Press, 2016

courses.name: Introduction to Topology
courses.objectives: Introduce fundamental concepts of topology, focusing on metric spaces and topological spaces.
content: Chapter 1: Metric Spaces - Definition, examples (ℝⁿ, function spaces), open and closed sets, neighborhoods, convergence, continuity in metric spaces
Chapter 2: Topological Spaces - Definition, basis, subbasis, open and closed sets, closure, interior, continuous functions, homeomorphisms
Chapter 3: Properties of Topological Spaces - Connectedness, path-connectedness, compactness, Heine-Borel theorem, separation axioms (Hausdorff spaces)
Chapter 4: Applications - Applications in analysis and geometry, introduction to manifolds (basic concepts)
references: J. R. Munkres, Topology, Pearson, 2000
S. Willard, General Topology, Dover, 2004
G. F. Simmons, Introduction to Topology and Modern Analysis, McGraw-Hill, 1963

courses.name: Numerical Analysis
courses.objectives: Introduce numerical methods for solving mathematical problems, with practical implementation.
courses.prerequisites: Analysis II, Algorithms and Data Structures I.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction to Numerical Analysis - Errors: round-off, truncation, stability and convergence of numerical methods
Chapter 2: Numerical Linear Algebra - Solving linear systems: direct methods (Gaussian elimination), iterative methods (Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel)
Chapter 3: Root Finding - Bisection method, Newton-Raphson method, fixed-point iteration
Chapter 4: Interpolation and Approximation - Polynomial interpolation: Lagrange, Newton, least squares approximation
Chapter 5: Numerical Integration - Trapezoidal rule, Simpson's rule, Gaussian quadrature
references: R. L. Burden & J. D. Faires, Numerical Analysis, Cengage Learning, 2010
A. Quarteroni et al., Numerical Mathematics, Springer, 2007
E. Suli & D. F. Mayers, An Introduction to Numerical Analysis, Cambridge University Press, 2003
courses.note: Practical work (TP) in Python or C

courses.name: Mathematics for Machine Learning 1
courses.objectives: Introduce mathematical foundations of machine learning, focusing on linear algebra, optimization, and probability.
courses.prerequisites: Algebra II, Probability and Descriptive Statistics, Introduction to Artificial Intelligence.
content: Chapter 1: Linear Algebra for Machine Learning - Matrix operations, eigenvalues, singular value decomposition, vector norms, matrix factorization
Chapter 2: Optimization - Gradient descent, stochastic gradient descent, convex optimization, loss functions
Chapter 3: Probability and Statistics - Probability distributions in machine learning, Bayesian inference, maximum likelihood estimation
Chapter 4: Introduction to Machine Learning Models - Linear regression, logistic regression, basic neural networks
references: I. Goodfellow et al., Deep Learning, MIT Press, 2016
K. P. Murphy, Machine Learning: A Probabilistic Perspective, MIT Press, 2012
M. P. Deisenroth et al., Mathematics for Machine Learning, Cambridge University Press, 2020
courses.note: Practical work includes implementing machine learning algorithms in Python using libraries like scikit-learn

courses.name: Graph Theory
courses.objectives: Provide an introduction to graph theory, focusing on basic concepts and applications in applied mathematics and computer science.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction to Graphs - Definitions: vertices, edges, directed/undirected graphs, types of graphs: simple, multigraphs, weighted graphs
Chapter 2: Graph Properties - Degree, paths, cycles, connectivity, components
Chapter 3: Trees and Spanning Trees - Properties of trees, minimum spanning trees (Kruskal's, Prim's algorithms)
Chapter 4: Applications - Graph coloring, shortest paths (Dijkstra's algorithm), applications in networks and optimization
references: R. Diestel, Graph Theory, Springer, 2017
J. A. Bondy & U. S. R. Murty, Graph Theory, Springer, 2008
D. B. West, Introduction to Graph Theory, Pearson, 2001

courses.name: Data Analysis
courses.objectives: Introduce techniques for data analysis, focusing on statistical methods and visualization for applied mathematics.
courses.prerequisites: Probability and Descriptive Statistics, Introduction to Data Visualization.
content: Chapter 1: Data Collection and Preparation - Data types, cleaning, handling missing values, data preprocessing techniques
Chapter 2: Exploratory Data Analysis - Descriptive statistics: mean, variance, quantiles, visualizations: scatter plots, box plots, heatmaps
Chapter 3: Statistical Analysis - Hypothesis testing, p-values, correlation and regression analysis
Chapter 4: Tools for Data Analysis - Using Python (pandas, Matplotlib, Seaborn), basic data analysis workflows
references: J. W. Tukey, Exploratory Data Analysis, Addison-Wesley, 1977
J. VanderPlas, Python Data Science Handbook, O'Reilly, 2016
D. C. Montgomery & G. C. Runger, Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers, Wiley, 2014

courses.name: Measure and Integration
courses.objectives: Introduce the theory of measure and integration, providing a foundation for advanced analysis and applications in probability and functional analysis.
content: Chapter 1: Sigma-Algebras and Measures - Sigma-algebras, measurable spaces, measures, properties, Lebesgue measure
Chapter 2: Measurable Functions - Definition, properties, simple functions, approximation
Chapter 3: Lebesgue Integration - Definition, comparison with Riemann integral, monotone and dominated convergence theorems, Fubini's theorem
Chapter 4: L^p Spaces - Definition, properties, Hölder and Minkowski inequalities
Chapter 5: Applications - Applications in probability and analysis, introduction to integration in infinite-dimensional spaces
references: W. Rudin, Real and Complex Analysis, McGraw-Hill, 1987
G. B. Folland, Real Analysis: Modern Techniques and Their Applications, Wiley, 1999
H. L. Royden, Real Analysis, Pearson, 1988

courses.name: Normed Vector Spaces
courses.objectives: Study normed vector spaces and their properties, laying the groundwork for functional analysis.
content: Chapter 1: Normed Vector Spaces - Definitions, examples (ℝⁿ, function spaces), norms, equivalent norms
Chapter 2: Banach Spaces - Completeness, examples, bounded linear operators
Chapter 3: Inner Product Spaces - Hilbert spaces, examples, orthogonality, projections
Chapter 4: Applications - Applications in optimization and approximation, introduction to spectral theory
references: E. Kreyszig, Introductory Functional Analysis with Applications, Wiley, 1989
J. B. Conway, A Course in Functional Analysis, Springer, 1990
W. Rudin, Functional Analysis, McGraw-Hill, 1991

courses.name: Differential Equations
courses.objectives: Deepen understanding of ordinary differential equations, focusing on theoretical and numerical methods.
content: Chapter 1: First-Order ODEs - Existence and uniqueness theorems, separable equations, exact equations
Chapter 2: Higher-Order Linear ODEs - Homogeneous and non-homogeneous equations, variation of parameters, method of undetermined coefficients
Chapter 3: Systems of ODEs - Linear systems, matrix methods, phase plane analysis, stability
Chapter 4: Numerical Methods - Euler's method, Runge-Kutta methods, stability and accuracy
references: W. E. Boyce & R. C. DiPrima, Elementary Differential Equations, Wiley, 2012
M. Braun, Differential Equations and Their Applications, Springer, 1993
G. F. Simmons, Differential Equations with Applications and Historical Notes, CRC Press, 2016
courses.note: Practical work includes numerical simulations in Python or MATLAB

courses.name: Mathematics for Machine Learning 2
courses.objectives: Build on Mathematics for Machine Learning 1 to explore advanced mathematical concepts for machine learning, including optimization and probabilistic models.
courses.prerequisites: Mathematics for Machine Learning 1, Numerical Analysis.
content: Chapter 1: Advanced Optimization - Convex optimization, Lagrange multipliers, gradient-based methods: Adam, RMSprop
Chapter 2: Probabilistic Models - Gaussian processes, Bayesian networks, Expectation-Maximization algorithm
Chapter 3: Dimensionality Reduction - Principal Component Analysis (PCA), Singular Value Decomposition (SVD)
Chapter 4: Advanced Machine Learning Models - Support Vector Machines, introduction to neural networks and deep learning
references: I. Goodfellow et al., Deep Learning, MIT Press, 2016
C. M. Bishop, Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning, Springer, 2006
M. P. Deisenroth et al., Mathematics for Machine Learning, Cambridge University Press, 2020
courses.note: Practical work includes implementing algorithms in Python using scikit-learn and TensorFlow

courses.name: Geometry
courses.objectives: Introduce fundamental concepts of geometry, focusing on Euclidean and non-Euclidean geometries.
content: Chapter 1: Euclidean Geometry - Axioms, congruence, similarity, transformations: translations, rotations, reflections
Chapter 2: Analytic Geometry - Coordinate geometry in ℝ² and ℝ³, lines, planes, conic sections
Chapter 3: Introduction to Non-Euclidean Geometry - Hyperbolic and spherical geometries, basic properties and models
Chapter 4: Applications - Geometric transformations in computer graphics, applications in physics and engineering
references: D. A. Brannan et al., Geometry, Cambridge University Press, 2011
H. S. M. Coxeter, Introduction to Geometry, Wiley, 1989
M. J. Greenberg, Euclidean and Non-Euclidean Geometries, W. H. Freeman, 2007

courses.name: Introduction to Machine Learning
courses.objectives: Provide a practical introduction to machine learning techniques, with emphasis on implementation and applications in data science.
courses.prerequisites: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence, Fundamentals of Programming and Scientific Computing with Python.
content: Chapter 1: Machine Learning Fundamentals - Supervised vs. unsupervised learning, model evaluation: train-test split, cross-validation
Chapter 2: Supervised Learning - Linear regression, logistic regression, decision trees, random forests
Chapter 3: Unsupervised Learning - Clustering: k-means, hierarchical clustering, dimensionality reduction: PCA, t-SNE
Chapter 4: Practical Implementation - Using scikit-learn for model building, data preprocessing and feature engineering
references: A. Géron, Hands-On Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn, Keras, and TensorFlow, O'Reilly, 2019
T. M. Mitchell, Machine Learning, McGraw-Hill, 1997
S. J. Russell & P. Norvig, Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach, Pearson, 2020
courses.note: Practical work includes Python-based projects using real datasets

courses.name: Entrepreneurship and Creativity Workshops
courses.objectives: Develop entrepreneurial skills and foster creativity through workshops, focusing on innovation in mathematics and applied fields.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction to Entrepreneurship - Concepts, entrepreneurial mindset, identifying opportunities in mathematics and technology
Chapter 2: Business Model Development - Business canvas model, market analysis, value proposition
Chapter 3: Creativity Workshops - Problem-solving techniques: brainstorming, design thinking, prototyping solutions for mathematical applications
Chapter 4: Project Development - Developing a mini-project or startup idea, presentation and pitching skills
references: E. Ries, The Lean Startup, Crown Business, 2011
T. Kelley & D. Kelley, Creative Confidence, Crown Business, 2013
P. F. Drucker, Innovation and Entrepreneurship, Routledge, 2007

courses.name: Introduction to Functional Analysis
courses.objectives: Introduce the principles of functional analysis, focusing on normed and Banach spaces, with applications in mathematics and physics.
content: Chapter 1: Normed and Banach Spaces - Review of normed spaces, completeness, examples: L^p spaces, function spaces
Chapter 2: Linear Operators - Bounded and continuous operators, operator norms, dual spaces
Chapter 3: Hilbert Spaces - Inner product spaces, orthogonality, Riesz representation theorem
Chapter 4: Spectral Theory - Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of operators, introduction to compact operators
Chapter 5: Applications - Applications in differential equations, weak convergence and applications
references: E. Kreyszig, Introductory Functional Analysis with Applications, Wiley, 1989
J. B. Conway, A Course in Functional Analysis, Springer, 1990
W. Rudin, Functional Analysis, McGraw-Hill, 1991

courses.name: Differential Geometry
courses.objectives: Study the geometry of differentiable manifolds, curves, and surfaces, with applications in physics and engineering.
content: Chapter 1: Differentiable Manifolds - Definition, charts, atlases, tangent spaces, differentiable maps
Chapter 2: Curves in ℝⁿ - Parameterized curves, arc length, curvature, torsion
Chapter 3: Surfaces in ℝ³ - First and second fundamental forms, Gaussian and mean curvature
Chapter 4: Riemannian Geometry - Metrics, geodesics, introduction to curvature tensors
Chapter 5: Applications - Applications in general relativity, geometric modeling in computer graphics
references: J. M. Lee, Introduction to Smooth Manifolds, Springer, 2012
M. P. do Carmo, Differential Geometry of Curves and Surfaces, Prentice-Hall, 1976
F. W. Warner, Foundations of Differentiable Manifolds and Lie Groups, Springer, 1983

courses.name: Inferential Statistics
courses.objectives: Provide a rigorous introduction to inferential statistics, focusing on estimation, hypothesis testing, and statistical modeling.
content: Chapter 1: Point Estimation - Estimators, bias, variance, maximum likelihood estimation
Chapter 2: Confidence Intervals - Construction of confidence intervals, intervals for means and proportions
Chapter 3: Hypothesis Testing - Null and alternative hypotheses, p-values, significance levels, tests for means, variances, and proportions
Chapter 4: Regression Analysis - Linear regression, multiple regression, model diagnostics, goodness of fit
Chapter 5: Practical Implementation - Statistical analysis using Python or R, case studies in data analysis
references: G. Casella & R. L. Berger, Statistical Inference, Duxbury, 2002
D. C. Montgomery & G. C. Runger, Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers, Wiley, 2014
J. A. Rice, Mathematical Statistics and Data Analysis, Duxbury, 2006

courses.name: Complex Analysis
courses.objectives: Study the theory of complex functions, including analyticity, contour integration, and applications.
content: Chapter 1: Complex Functions - Complex differentiation, analytic functions, Cauchy-Riemann equations
Chapter 2: Contour Integration - Complex integrals, Cauchy's theorem, Cauchy's integral formula
Chapter 3: Series and Residues - Power series, Taylor and Laurent series, residue theorem, applications
Chapter 4: Applications - Conformal mappings, applications in physics and engineering
references: L. V. Ahlfors, Complex Analysis, McGraw-Hill, 1979
J. B. Conway, Functions of One Complex Variable, Springer, 1978
E. M. Stein & R. Shakarchi, Complex Analysis, Princeton University Press, 2003
courses.note: Practical work includes numerical computations in complex analysis

courses.name: Partial Differential Equations
courses.objectives: Introduce partial differential equations (PDEs), their classification, and solution methods, with applications in physics and engineering.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction to PDEs - Classification: elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic, examples: Laplace, heat, wave equations
Chapter 2: First-Order PDEs - Method of characteristics, linear and quasilinear equations
Chapter 3: Second-Order PDEs - Separation of variables, Fourier series solutions
Chapter 4: Numerical Methods - Finite difference methods, stability and convergence
references: L. C. Evans, Partial Differential Equations, AMS, 2010
W. A. Strauss, Partial Differential Equations: An Introduction, Wiley, 2007
R. Haberman, Applied Partial Differential Equations, Pearson, 2012
courses.note: Practical work includes numerical simulations in Python or MATLAB

courses.name: Big Data and Cloud Computing
courses.objectives: Introduce concepts of big data and cloud computing, focusing on tools and techniques for handling large datasets in applied mathematics and data science.
courses.prerequisites: Introduction to Machine Learning, Fundamentals of Programming and Scientific Computing with Python.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction to Big Data - Characteristics of big data: volume, velocity, variety, big data applications in mathematics and science
Chapter 2: Big Data Technologies - Hadoop ecosystem: HDFS, MapReduce, Apache Spark: RDDs, DataFrames
Chapter 3: Cloud Computing Fundamentals - Cloud service models: IaaS, PaaS, SaaS, cloud providers: AWS, Azure, Google Cloud
Chapter 4: Practical Implementation - Data processing with Spark, deploying simple applications on cloud platforms
references: T. White, Hadoop: The Definitive Guide, O'Reilly, 2015
M. Zaharia et al., Learning Spark, O'Reilly, 2020
A. Silberschatz et al., Database System Concepts, McGraw-Hill, 2019
courses.note: Practical work includes hands-on exercises using Python and Spark

courses.name: Scientific Methodology and Writing
courses.objectives: Develop skills in scientific methodology and writing, focusing on research methods and communication in mathematics.
content: Chapter 1: Scientific Methodology - Research design, hypothesis formulation, literature review techniques
Chapter 2: Scientific Writing - Structure of scientific papers, writing abstracts, introductions, conclusions
Chapter 3: Presentation Skills - Preparing and delivering scientific presentations, visual aids and data visualization
Chapter 4: Ethics in Research - Plagiarism, citation practices, ethical considerations in mathematical research
references: G. Pólya, How to Solve It, Princeton University Press, 2004
N. J. Higham, Handbook of Writing for the Mathematical Sciences, SIAM, 1998
J. M. Cargal, A Guide to Writing Mathematics, 2000

courses.name: Advanced Probability
courses.objectives: Provide a rigorous foundation in advanced probability theory, focusing on measure-theoretic approaches and applications in statistics and data science.
content: Chapter 1: Probability Spaces - Sigma-algebras, probability measures, random variables, expectation, variance
Chapter 2: Convergence of Random Variables - Almost sure convergence, convergence in probability, law of large numbers, central limit theorem
Chapter 3: Conditional Probability and Expectation - Conditional distributions, conditional expectation, introduction to martingales
Chapter 4: Applications - Applications in statistical inference, introduction to stochastic modeling
references: P. Billingsley, Probability and Measure, Wiley, 1995
R. Durrett, Probability: Theory and Examples, Cambridge University Press, 2019
J. Rosenthal, A First Look at Rigorous Probability Theory, World Scientific, 2006

courses.name: Introduction to Stochastic Processes
courses.objectives: Introduce stochastic processes, focusing on their properties and applications in modeling random phenomena.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction to Stochastic Processes - Definition, classification (discrete vs. continuous time), examples: Markov chains, Poisson processes
Chapter 2: Markov Chains - Transition probabilities, stationary distributions, applications in modeling
Chapter 3: Poisson Processes - Definition, inter-arrival times, applications in queueing theory
Chapter 4: Brownian Motion - Definition, properties, introduction to applications in finance and physics
references: S. M. Ross, Introduction to Probability Models, Academic Press, 2014
G. R. Grimmett & D. R. Stirzaker, Probability and Random Processes, Oxford University Press, 2020
J. R. Norris, Markov Chains, Cambridge University Press, 1998

courses.name: Deep Learning and Physics-Informed Neural Networks
courses.objectives: Explore advanced deep learning techniques, including physics-informed neural networks (PINNs), for solving scientific problems.
courses.prerequisites: Deep Learning, Mathematics for Machine Learning 2.
content: Chapter 1: Advanced Neural Network Architectures - Review of deep neural networks, attention mechanisms, transformers
Chapter 2: Physics-Informed Neural Networks - Incorporating physical laws into neural networks, loss functions with PDE constraints
Chapter 3: Training and Optimization - Advanced optimization techniques: Adam, L-BFGS, handling high-dimensional data
Chapter 4: Applications - Solving PDEs with PINNs, applications in fluid dynamics, quantum mechanics
references: I. Goodfellow et al., Deep Learning, MIT Press, 2016

M. Raissi et al., Physics-Informed Neural Networks: A Deep Learning Framework for Solving Forward and Inverse Problems Involving Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations, Journal of Computational Physics, 2019
A. Géron, Hands-On Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn, Keras, and TensorFlow, O'Reilly, 2019

courses.name: Natural Language Processing (NLP)
courses.objectives: Introduce natural language processing techniques, focusing on text processing and machine learning models for language tasks.
courses.prerequisites: Introduction to Machine Learning, Deep Learning.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction to NLP - Text preprocessing: tokenization, stemming, lemmatization, bag-of-words, TF-IDF
Chapter 2: Word Embeddings - Word2Vec, GloVe, contextual embeddings (BERT)
Chapter 3: NLP Models - Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs), LSTMs, transformer models for text classification, sentiment analysis
Chapter 4: Practical Implementation - Building NLP pipelines with Python (NLTK, spaCy, Hugging Face), applications: text classification, named entity recognition
references: D. Jurafsky & J. H. Martin, Speech and Language Processing, Pearson, 2020
J. Eisenstein, Introduction to Natural Language Processing, MIT Press, 2019
Y. Goldberg, Neural Network Methods for Natural Language Processing, Morgan & Claypool, 2017
courses.note: Practical work includes implementing NLP models in Python

courses.name: Computer Vision
courses.objectives: Introduce computer vision techniques, focusing on image processing and deep learning models for vision tasks.
courses.prerequisites: Introduction to Machine Learning, Deep Learning.
content: Chapter 1: Image Processing Basics - Image representation, filtering, edge detection, feature extraction
Chapter 2: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) - Architecture: convolutional layers, pooling, training CNNs for image classification
Chapter 3: Advanced Vision Models - Object detection (YOLO, Faster R-CNN), image segmentation (U-Net)
Chapter 4: Practical Implementation - Building vision models with TensorFlow or PyTorch, applications: facial recognition, autonomous driving
references: R. Szeliski, Computer Vision: Algorithms and Applications, Springer, 2022
S. J. D. Prince, Computer Vision: Models, Learning, and Inference, Cambridge University Press, 2012
A. Géron, Hands-On Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn, Keras, and TensorFlow, O'Reilly, 2019
courses.note: Practical work includes implementing vision models in Python

courses.name: Time Series
courses.objectives: Introduce time series analysis, focusing on modeling and forecasting techniques for temporal data.
content: Chapter 1: Introduction to Time Series - Characteristics of time series data, stationarity, autocorrelation
Chapter 2: Time Series Models - Moving average, autoregressive models, ARIMA models
Chapter 3: Forecasting - Forecasting techniques: exponential smoothing, evaluating forecast accuracy
Chapter 4: Applications - Time series analysis in finance, economics, visualization of time series data
references: R. H. Shumway & D. S. Stoffer, Time Series Analysis and Its Applications, Springer, 2017
C. Chatfield, The Analysis of Time Series: An Introduction, Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2019
G. E. P. Box et al., Time Series Analysis: Forecasting and Control, Wiley, 2015

courses.name: Ethics and History of Modern Mathematics
courses.objectives: Explore ethical issues in mathematical and data science applications, alongside the historical development of modern mathematics.
content: Chapter 1: History of Modern Mathematics - Development of key concepts: analysis, probability, computing, contributions of mathematicians (e.g., Turing, von Neumann)
Chapter 2: Ethics in Mathematics and Data Science - Ethical issues in AI and data science, bias, fairness, privacy concerns
Chapter 3: Case Studies - Historical mathematical controversies, ethical dilemmas in modern applications (e.g., AI ethics)
Chapter 4: Discussion and Reflection - Debating ethical principles, writing reflective essays on mathematics and society
references: M. Kline, Mathematics and the Search for Knowledge, Oxford University Press, 1985
C. D. Hollings, Mathematics Across the Iron Curtain: A History of the Algebraic Theory of Semigroups, AMS, 2014
S. O. Hansson, The Ethics of Technology, Rowman & Littlefield, 2018
